BULONG PROJECT 
 TENEMENT: P25/1726 
 EAST COOLGARDIE (BULONG) MINERAL FIELD 
 Kurnalpi (SH51-10) 1:250,000 Sheet 
 Kanowna (3236) 1:100,000 Sheet 
 ANNUAL REPORT

18.text: Works  completed  during  the  2006  reporting  year  comprised  of  field  reconnaissance,  an  open  file  data

19.text: review,  and  aeromagnetic  interpretation  and  regional  geological  assessment  as  part  of  a  review  of  the

20.text: Bulong Project as a whole.  This report details these works.

text:
Works  completed  during  the  2006  reporting  year  comprised  of  field  reconnaissance,  an  open  file  data 
 review,  and  aeromagnetic  interpretation  and  regional  geological  assessment  as  part  of  a  review  of  the 
 Bulong Project as a whole.  This report details these works.

22.text: The tenement covers an east west spur off a north south trending drainage channel.  Relief is variable with

23.text: lows associated with the drainage channel and higher relief associated with serpentinised ultramafic rocks in

24.text: the south east corner of the tenement.

26.text: The area is semi-arid with only sporadic and moderate rainfall during the winter months. Occasional summer

27.text: thunderstorms  with  associated  showers  are  restricted  to  periods  of  major  cyclone  activity  in  the  northern

text:
The tenement covers an east west spur off a north south trending drainage channel.  Relief is variable with 
 lows associated with the drainage channel and higher relief associated with serpentinised ultramafic rocks in 
 the south east corner of the tenement.  
 The area is semi-arid with only sporadic and moderate rainfall during the winter months. Occasional summer 
 thunderstorms  with  associated  showers  are  restricted  to  periods  of  major  cyclone  activity  in  the  northern

33.text: Tenement P25/1726 was originally acquired by Bulong Operations Pty Ltd then transferred to Bulong Nickel

34.text: Pty Ltd who subsequently went into receivership.  The tenement was acquired by Hampton Nickel Ltd, (a

35.text: wholly owned subsidiary of Heron Resources Ltd) in July 2006.

23.text: Mont Monger Fault, and is divisible into two major areas. The northern portion is bimodal mafic and felsic

24.text: volcanics. The southern portion is centred about the Bulong anticline, a dome structure plunging both north

25.text: and south. The eastern limb is dominated by mafic materials and contrasts to the western limb (the Bulong

26.text: Complex of Ahmat 1995) which is dominated by komatiite flows forming the proto-ore for LionOre’s Boulder

27.text: Block  Pit  (now  owned  by  Heron  Resources).  The  core  of  the  anticline  is  composed  of  a  calc-alkaline

text:
Mont Monger Fault, and is divisible into two major areas. The northern portion is bimodal mafic and felsic 
 volcanics. The southern portion is centred about the Bulong anticline, a dome structure plunging both north 
 and south. The eastern limb is dominated by mafic materials and contrasts to the western limb (the Bulong 
 Complex of Ahmat 1995) which is dominated by komatiite flows forming the proto-ore for LionOre’s Boulder 
 Block  Pit  (now  owned  by  Heron  Resources).  The  core  of  the  anticline  is  composed  of  a  calc-alkaline

32.text: The majority of P25/1726 coincides with an east-west ‘arm’ off a north-south trending drainage channel. The

33.text: tenement is covered with alluvium and the only outcrop observed is restricted to undifferentiated ultramafics

34.text: in the south east corner of the tenement.  The ultramafic assemblage is prospective for laterite nickel.

36.text: Lateritic nickel deposits have formed over Archaean ultramafic rocks comprising the Bulong Complex that

37.text: covers an area of 4 km wide by 50 km long. The Complex is confined by faults within the assemblages of

38.text: greenstone  and  granitic  rocks  of  the  Gindalbie  Terrane.  The  ultramafics  are  originally  derived  from  a

39.text: sequence of komatiites intercalated with felsic to intermediate rocks.  Individual units are differentiated into

40.text: gabbros,  norites  and  olivine-rich  mesocumulates  and  orthocumulate  peridotites  with  minor  dunite.  The

41.text: ultramafics are extensively serpentinised and dip steeply to the west.

43.text: The weathering of the ultramafics has leached out the more soluble components (Mg, Si, Ca, alkalis) leaving

44.text: behind a residual mass of iron and aluminium hydroxides. Much of the silica and magnesia is retained in the

45.text: weathering  profile  in  the  form  of  nontronite  clays,  sheets  and  lenses  of  silica,  and  magnesite  veins  and

46.text: deposits. The weathering profile averages 34 metres thick but displays considerable variation from place to

49.text: There  is  clear  evidence  of  supergene  enrichment  of  nickel  and  cobalt  since  both  elements  are  less

50.text: concentrated  in  the  top  (oldest)  part  of  the  weathering  profile.  However,  contrary  to  many  other  laterite

51.text: deposits in the world, cobalt and nickel do not show different zones of supergene concentration at Bulong.

53.text: The relative prevalence of ore types varies considerably among the various Bulong area deposits, however,

54.text: serpentine and nontronite ore types make up nearly 85% of the total resource.

text:
The majority of P25/1726 coincides with an east-west ‘arm’ off a north-south trending drainage channel. The 
 tenement is covered with alluvium and the only outcrop observed is restricted to undifferentiated ultramafics 
 in the south east corner of the tenement.  The ultramafic assemblage is prospective for laterite nickel. 
 Lateritic nickel deposits have formed over Archaean ultramafic rocks comprising the Bulong Complex that 
 covers an area of 4 km wide by 50 km long. The Complex is confined by faults within the assemblages of 
 greenstone  and  granitic  rocks  of  the  Gindalbie  Terrane.  The  ultramafics  are  originally  derived  from  a 
 sequence of komatiites intercalated with felsic to intermediate rocks.  Individual units are differentiated into 
 gabbros,  norites  and  olivine-rich  mesocumulates  and  orthocumulate  peridotites  with  minor  dunite.  The 
 ultramafics are extensively serpentinised and dip steeply to the west. 
 The weathering of the ultramafics has leached out the more soluble components (Mg, Si, Ca, alkalis) leaving 
 behind a residual mass of iron and aluminium hydroxides. Much of the silica and magnesia is retained in the 
 weathering  profile  in  the  form  of  nontronite  clays,  sheets  and  lenses  of  silica,  and  magnesite  veins  and 
 deposits. The weathering profile averages 34 metres thick but displays considerable variation from place to 
 There  is  clear  evidence  of  supergene  enrichment  of  nickel  and  cobalt  since  both  elements  are  less 
 concentrated  in  the  top  (oldest)  part  of  the  weathering  profile.  However,  contrary  to  many  other  laterite 
 deposits in the world, cobalt and nickel do not show different zones of supergene concentration at Bulong.   
 The relative prevalence of ore types varies considerably among the various Bulong area deposits, however, 
 serpentine and nontronite ore types make up nearly 85% of the total resource.  
 The laterite profile at Bulong is generally subdivided into the following zones: 
 •  Limonite (ferruginous clay) zone 
 •  Nontronite (smectite clay) zone 
 •  Saprolite (serpentine) zone 
 •  Unweathered serpentinised bedrock zone

77.text: Trial mining was carried out at the Pinta deposit including

78.text: determinations of bulk densities, moisture factors, mineability,

79.text: trafficability, and metallurgical testing. A 20x20 metre square pit was

80.text: selected in the western part of the Pinta deposit with access and pit

81.text: walls developed outside of the square. The final pit was excavated to

82.text: a depth of 27m. The trial mining exercise was part of the feasibility

83.text: study to determine the geological, mining and processing

84.text: requirements for developing the Bulong operation. The following

85.text: information was gathered from this trial mining exercise:

87.text: The laterite profile was comprised of four zones: Limonite,

88.text: Nontronite, Upper Saprolite, and Lower Saprolite.

89.text: Nickel grades declined with depth from the top of the clay zone.

30.text: Subsequent  to  the  acquisition  of  the  tenement,  an  open  file  data  review  of  historic  exploration  data  was

31.text: completed.  This review was part of a review and compilation of data over the Bulong Project as a whole.

32.text: Although a search of open file mineral exploration reports located a number of reports of interest to future

33.text: work on the Bulong Project as a whole, very little data was located for the area that comprises P25/1726.

text:
Subsequent  to  the  acquisition  of  the  tenement,  an  open  file  data  review  of  historic  exploration  data  was 
 completed.  This review was part of a review and compilation of data over the Bulong Project as a whole. 
 Although a search of open file mineral exploration reports located a number of reports of interest to future 
 work on the Bulong Project as a whole, very little data was located for the area that comprises P25/1726. 
 5.2 Aeromagnetic Interpretation 
 Aeromagnetic  interpretation  of  regional  multiclient  TMI  data  supported  the  geological  assessment  that  the 
 tenement covers ultramafic peridotite and confirmed the presence of ultramafic material beneath the alluvial
